Cya tuesday, Alloran!

::Prowl/Kluster/Grimmler/Proto/Firearm/FZ/Perndabot::

Prowl growled as Angel Prime's transmission was played back to him by 
his com. Bots like him were exatly what had kept the Maximals back 
throughout the Beast Wars. While leaders were considered weak, they 
were hampered by the bots that spoke out against them, and could do 
nothing but indeed be weak. Prowl could feel the dissapointment from 
Iron Raptor, and hear her thoughts, and that didn't improve the 
situation.

-Don't worry, my love, you're faring better than Liono did. They can 
yell at you, but they are under your command, and as long as you make 
good decisions, they will remain so.- He replied to her, looking at 
the Maximals. He watched several of them report in, and then looked 
at FZ. There was little doubt why the Alliance had gotten the upper 
hand in the war: the Maximals were slow to rally.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Kluster approached Iron Raptor, saluting with his one remaining hand.

"Kluster reporting, Ma'am!"

Behind him, a battered Grimmler also saluted. "Grimmler reporting."
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
A nearly-dead Proto stumbled into the cluster of Maximals, also 
saluting. "Proto reporting, commander."
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Firearm walked back to the Maximals around IR, also saluting 
her. "Firearm here."
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
FZ looked over at the Maximals, shaking his head. It was no wonder 
they had failed to defend themselves at this battle, not with them 
being so divided. He watched calmly as one of their number began 
preparing for an attack.

FZ activated his comm to Iron Raptor's frequency. "You do realize 
that if your troops continue to fire, mine will be forced to destroy 
your base?"

Closing the link to IR, he opened one to Deemos. "Deemos, would you 
mind telling the Chosen Ones to stand down? The battle is over, we 
have won, and I'm negotiating us getting some troops back from this."

Closing that connection, he looked around, waiting.
